sn55.54:4.1: At one time the Buddha was staying in the land of the Sakyans, near Kapilavatthu in the Banyan Tree Monastery.
sn55.54:4.2: At that time several mendicants were making a robe for the Buddha, thinking that
sn55.54:4.3: when his robe was finished and the three months of the rains residence had passed the Buddha would set out wandering.
sn55.54:4.4: Mahānāma the Sakyan heard about this.
sn55.54:4.7: Then he went up to the Buddha,
sn55.54:4.8: bowed, sat down to one side,
sn55.54:4.9: and told him that he had heard that the Buddha was leaving. He added:
sn55.54:4.13: “Sir, I haven’t heard and learned it directly from the Buddha how a wise lay follower should advise another wise lay follower who is sick, suffering, gravely ill.”
sn55.54:5.1: “Mahānāma, a wise lay follower should put at ease another wise lay follower who is sick, suffering, gravely ill with four consolations.
sn55.54:5.3: You have experiential confidence in the Buddha …
sn55.54:5.8: And you have the ethical conduct loved by the noble ones …
sn55.54:6.1: When wise lay follower has put at ease another wise lay follower who is sick, suffering, gravely ill with these four consolations, they should say:
sn55.54:6.2: ‘Do you worry about your mother and father?’
sn55.54:6.5: ‘But sir, it’s your nature to die.
sn55.54:6.6: Whether or not you worry about your mother and father,
sn55.54:6.8: It would be good to give up worrying about your mother and father.’
sn55.54:7.2: ‘I have given up worrying about my mother and father,’ they should say:
sn55.54:7.3: ‘But do you worry about your partners and children?’
sn55.54:7.6: ‘But sir, it’s your nature to die.
sn55.54:7.7: Whether or not you worry about your partners and children,
sn55.54:7.9: It would be good to give up worrying about your partners and children.’
sn55.54:8.2: ‘I have given up worrying about my partner,’ they should say:
sn55.54:8.3: ‘But do you worry about the five kinds of human sensual stimulation?’
sn55.54:8.6: ‘Good sir, heavenly sensual pleasures are better than human sensual pleasures.
sn55.54:8.7: It would be good to turn your mind away from human sensual pleasures and fix it on the gods of the Four Great Kings.’
sn55.54:9.2: ‘I have done so,’ they should say:
sn55.54:9.3: ‘Good sir, the gods of the Thirty Three are better than the gods of the Four Great Kings …
sn55.54:10.5: the Gods Who Love to Create …
sn55.54:10.6: the Gods Who Control the Creations of Others …
sn55.54:10.7: the Gods of the Brahmā realm are better than the Gods Who Control the Creations of Others.
sn55.54:10.8: It would be good to turn your mind away from the Gods Who Control the Creations of Others and fix it on the gods of the Brahmā realm.’
sn55.54:10.10: ‘I have do so,’ they should say:
sn55.54:10.11: ‘Good sir, the Brahmā realm is impermanent, not lasting, and included within identity.
sn55.54:10.12: It would be good to turn your mind away from the Brahmā realm and apply it to the cessation of identity.’
sn55.54:11.3: then there is no difference between a lay follower whose mind is freed in this way and a mendicant whose mind is freed from defilements; that is,
sn55.54:11.4: between the freedom of one and the other.”
